dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright, unpretentious two-bedroom in a pre-war building cluttered with books and papers, reflecting its owner’s lively mind. The decor is that of a perennial grad studen digs, the bachelor pad of a New York intellectual. A dog curled up on the sofa beside him, DAVID LIPSKY, a boyishly handsome forty-three, quick-witted, tightly-woun smokes and types speedily from scraps of handwritten note surrounded by books on his current journalistic subject, climate change. A stack of copies of his recent publishin success - Absolutely American - looms nearby. His iPhone vibrates. He gets up and answers the call.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob, what’s up?

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) Listen: According to this unconfirmed report... David Wallace is dead.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (disputing) What? No no no no, must be a college prank or something... Lipsky rapidly googles “david foster wallace death” and s the news.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I thought if anybody knew whether it was true or not... Shock registers on Lipsky’s face. OVER: NPR reporter ROBE SIEGEL.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT SIEGEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now a remembrance of writer David Foster Wallace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky is being escorted to a booth by a college-age INTE

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT SIEGEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He was found dead, an apparent suicide, on Friday night. Wallace's novel, "Infinite Jest," brought him fame and a wide audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky, wearing headphones, heart pounding, nervously wai for a cue from a woman producer in the control booth.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT SIEGEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .--Writer David Lipsky has this appreciation. The producer signals to Lipsky, who reads his prepared remarks from his shaky hands.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: “To read David Foster Wallace was to feel your eyelids pulled open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky, pensive, smoking, walks down the street on a cris autumn day, stops at a window display honoring Wallace wi his picture and copies of his books The Broom of the Syst Brief Interviews with Hideous Men, A Supposedly Fun Thing I'1l Never Do Again and his magnum opus, Infinite Jest.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some writers specialize in the away- from-home experience. They’ve safaried, eaten across Italy, covered awar. Wallace offered his alive self... INT. LIPSKY’S WEST END AVE APT/CLOSET - NYC - 2008 - DAY Lipsky rummages closet shelves until he locates a particu shoe box labeled “DFW.” He opens the box: inside are a motley bunch of audio tapes - eight or nine of them - numbered, scrawled with dates from four days in March 199

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-.cutting through our sleepy aquarium, our standard T.V., stores, political campaigns. Writers who can do this, like Salinger and Fitzgerald, forge an unbreakable bond with readers... He digs out a quaintly clunky SONY tape recorder that was state-of-the-art back in 1996. It doesn’t play. He remove its batteries and looks in drawers for new ones. No luck.
INT. LIPSKY’S WEST END AVE APT/BATHROOM/OFFICE - NYC - 20

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Lipsky takes the batteries out of his electric toothbrush puts them in the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t slip into the books looking for story, information, but for a particular experience. The sensation, for a certain number of pages, of being David Foster Wallace.” With a mixture of excitement and trepidation, he inserts cassette #1 in the machine and presses play. The sound of David's voice mid-tape, is both comforting and moving. DAVID’S VOICE (on the recording) -- there was, if anything, a conscious attempt to not give overt direction. Although, of course, you end up becoming yourself. LIPSKY’S VOICE (on the recording) Did they want you to be a writer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blurry, indistinct POV shot of DAVID FOSTER WALLACE in passenger seat of a moving car: Lipsky’s memory strugglin come into focus. DAVID’S VOICE No, the big thing when I was little, I was like a really serious jock...

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIPSKY’S WEST END AVE APT/OFFICE - NYC - 2008 - DAY Lipsky listens. DAVID’S VOICE ...city-wide football as a kid. I was real big, really strong as a kid. And then for four or five years, I was gonna be a pro tennis player. My great dream. Reading was just kind of fun. A weird thing that I did on the side -  10 11 14 Lipsky stops and presses rewind on the tape player. He ruminates as we HEAR the whir of the tape rewinding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heart-stopping view of the illuminated twin towers te us we are in pre-2001 New York.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (reads) “I didn’t understand SoHo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky stands before a paltry turnout - consisting of old people and a few loyal friends (among them his pretty girlfriend, SARAH) - reading from his novel, The Art Fair Here, Lipsky is 30 years old but looks like a student, hi long, dark, Byronic hair framing his fine features.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - the warehouses, the old buildings, the cobbled streets. Distracted by disinterested CUSTOMERS who continue to bro Lipsky hears a muffled giggle and sees a YOUNG COUPLE in audience flirting and clearly not listening.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It wasn’t the Upper East Side, and it was dirty. I felt marooned. Our mother had taken us off the track of the nice life we’d been on. She’d moored us in a creepy cul-de-sac with her art-world friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deafening music. A crowded, noisy gathering of mostly you cool, black-attired New York writers and artists.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: None of the kids in my school had parents in the art world. It made me feel different. Like there was something I had to cover up.” Lipsky gets two glasses of wine from a bar. We FOLLOW as makes his way through the crowd. He knows a lot of people with whom he exchanges ad-libbed greetings along the way. They have to SHOUT to be heard above the din.  15

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: David, hi! How'd your reading go?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: BEARDED GUY
dialogues.text: Sorry I missed it!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it! Drinks held aloft, Lipsky continues into the crowd. A MOD

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: I heard you got the Rolling Stone job!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: We'll see! I’m sort of on probation! Lipsky delivers the drink to Sarah, who stands in a circl acquaintances in mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S FRIEND
dialogues.text: Did you see Kirn’s review in New York Magazine? The guy’s been fucking canonized!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: David Foster Wallace. INT. LIPSKY’S W 77TH ST APT/BEDROOM/BATHROOM - NYC - 1996

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Lipsky, at the bathroom door, reads aloud Walter Kirn’s review in New York magazine (2/12/96). Sarah comes out in towel and he follows her to the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: “Next year’s book awards have been decided.” Can you believe this? “The plaques and citations can now be put into escrow.” Unbelievable. “With Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace - a plutonium-dense, satirical whiz-kid opus that runs to almost a thousand pages — She kisses him as she goes past.  16 17

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (CONTD)
dialogues.text: - (not including footnotes) - the competition has been obliterated. It’s as though Paul Bunyan had joined the NFL or Wittgenstein had gone on Jeopardy! The novel is that colossally disruptive. And that spectacularly good.” That’s the fucking opening paragraph!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What if it actually is that good? You know? You may just have to read it. INT. LIPSKY’S W 77TH ST APT/LIVING ROOM - NYC - 1996 - DU If his 2008 place is grad-student-y, the 1996 Lipsky residence is smaller and explosively chaotic, like a teenager’s domain. We find Sarah on the couch reading the current bestseller, Primary Colors and Lipsky beside her reading Infinite Jest. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzzing with the hip, youthful industry of people who kno they’re at the place to be. Lipsky drops by to see his editor, BOB LEVIN, 40, greying, bearded.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: How many times have we interviewed a writer in the last ten years? Guess.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Um... how many?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Zero. I checked.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s because Rolling Stone doesn’t interview writers.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: There hasn't been a writer like this one. Once in a generation, maybe. Hemingway, Pynchon. Let me have this story.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 20 21 Lipsky tosses Newsweek, opened to a photo of Wallace, ont Bob’s messy desk.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: He’s finishing up his book tour and I want to go with him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That’s not a story.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: He teaches at some small state university, somewhere in Illinois. Send me there. Please, Bob. This is the sort of stuff I should be doing, not 500-words on boy bands. Talk to Jann?

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Lipsky works at his computer. Newsweek with the Wallace photo lands on his desk. Lipsky looks up and sees Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: There had better be a story there... Bob leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (calls) There will be! His smile fades. Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah reads her own copy of Infinite Jest as Lipsky walks back and forth across frame, gathering stuff to pack for trip. Laptop. Notebook. Wallace's books, full of notation and post-its. Tape recorder, packs of audio cassettes. He considers then tosses in The Art Fair and zips up his bag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey wintry morning. Lipsky, outside his building, hail taxi.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAB/FDR DRIVE
dialogues.text: Lipsky, in the backseat, reads Infinite Jest; he’s about three-quarters of the way through it. He makes a note in margin, then glances out the window at the passing skylin  22 25 26 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American Airlines plane comes in for a landing on the flat, grey, wintry landscape.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/OUTSKIRTS
dialogues.text: Lipsky, on the road, drives past a sign for Bloomington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American landscape of fast-food places and chain store Lipsky’s Grand Am is parked in a 7-Eleven and Citco stati He stands at a pay phone. (We never intercut during telephone conversations.) DAVID’S VOICE (over phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: David, hi, it’s David Lipsky. DAVID’S VOICE Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I think I may have made a wrong turn somewhere. Let’s see, I’m on County Highway 29, across from Circus Video? DAVID’S VOICE How'd you get this number?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Your publicist sent it in her e-mail, just in case. DAVID’S VOICE You'd do me a favor by losing it.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/DAVID'S STREET
dialogues.text: Stormy skies. Flat, wintry terrain. As the car pulls up, Lipsky sees, through the windshield, a modest, one-story brick house in the distance, and a man emerging from it. From Lipsky’s long shot POV: DAVID FOSTER WALLACE, hands shoved in his jeans pockets for warmth, accompanied by hi two barking, rambunctious black labs, JEEVES and DRONE. Lipsky parks. He takes a deep, bracing breath before gett out of the car to finally meet the man about whom he has complicated feelings. He walks toward him. This is the first time we see David up close and in focu stubble, long hair, blue bandanna, wire-rims, Frye boots, 6'2” and, at this time in his life, burly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You made it.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hi. David offers his wary, tolerant hand. This being the end his tour, his patience is frayed and he’s just about talk out. But, at the same time, it’s Rolling Stone, he wants make a good impression.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dave. Dave Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: David Lipsky. Pleasure. Lipsky is cowed but determined to hold his own. These are two really smart, competitive guys out to impress each ot Wallace wants to be favorably profiled and Lipsky wants Wallace’s approval - and a good story.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Sorry about the phone call.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: 95% joke. Lipsky laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONTD)
dialogues.text: Sorry in advance about the dogs, gonna be slobbering all over you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t mind. I love dogs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, you haven’t met these guys... It’s cold, let’s go inside. (to the dogs) Jeeves, Drone! Get over here! Lipsky follows David and the rowdy, barking dogs into the house.  28 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky drops his bag on the messy, shit-stained shag carp The dogs are indeed all over him. Lipsky scratches their heads and speaks to them as a dog lover would speak to do

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m very glad to meet you, too. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s Jeeves. The Jeevesmeister. I got him ‘cause he was so ugly. No one else wanted him. Now he’s like a Cover Girl-dog. Aren't you, Jeeves? Yes, you are. And this is Drone. My provisional dog.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why provisional?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just showed up one day while Jeeves and I were out jogging and the rest is history. (A beat.) I feel like I should offer you tea or something.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks. That would be great. David goes to put on water. We STAY on Lipsky, casually studying the room with the eye of a journalist, taking in grad-student-like accoutrements: cramped cinder-block bookshelves; hodgepodge of furniture, an ALANIS MORISSETT POSTER conspicuously on the wall. Lipsky, glancing out th window at the wintry landscape, raises his voice to conve with David, who’s in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Nice view.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank you. I can’t take credit for it. Lipsky smiles. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: So... Have you always been unlisted?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen) I had to do that recently. It was getting crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of fans?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know if “fan” would be the right word... I think what happened was, I had forgotten to tell my parents not to give my number out. So it was people who tracked my parents down, and um -

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (knowing) Ohhh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I have this terrible problem, I just really hate to hurt people’s feelings. So I did something kinda cowardly.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Unlisting your number’s not cowardly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It kinda is. I mean, I changed my number so these folks couldn’t find me anymore. There was this computer operator in Vancouver, lived in a basement. Who I found really moving. In terrible terrible pain.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What did he want from you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wasn’t clear, and when I would sort of ask him, he’d get angry, and that’s when it got scary. Lipsky sees a child’s drawing displayed on the fridge: “Chickenhead Dave Wallace.”

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (re: the drawing) Who’s the artist?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hm? (Lipsky points.) Oh, my friend's daughter. Calls me Chickenhead, and I call her Chickenhead. Her latest salvo in the war. Laughing, Lipsky takes out his tape recorder and starts t set it up but stops. (Lipsky is a nervous laugher; he lau a_lot, not only where indicated.)  12.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You mind if I...?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey. Do what you’ve got to do. David watches uncomfortably. The ever-present tape record becomes a third character in this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listen: Before we start putting stuff on tape, I gotta ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I need to know that anything that I ask you five minutes later to not put in, you won’t put in.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. He clicks off the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Given my level of fatigue and fuck-up quotient lately, it’s the only way I can see doin’ it and not going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I understand completely. Lipsky presses play.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Right back on, huh.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You agreed to the interview.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/MAIN STREET
dialogues.text: Lipsky at the wheel. David chewing tobacco. Ad-libs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: .--There’1l be signs for the school on the right.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You like teaching there?  31

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do, very much, that’s what’s so fucked, I feel so bad for these kids.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why do you feel bad them, they have the best writing teacher in the world.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If I were there, maybe. The whole fuss has taken me out of school for the past two weeks and I’m gonna have to leave again tomorrow. We've got to get up at the crack of dawn to leave for the airport, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, do we really?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's what you signed on for, man. You're welcome to stick around, write an article about my dogs. Might be more interesting, I promise you. David spits chewed tobacco into a Savarin can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Lipsky walk to his classroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do yourself a favor, don’t expect any fireworks in there...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class in-progress. Lipsky observes as David paces. He “on” and his students are eating it up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A campus romance story, I gotta tell ya, to the average citizen, is not all that interesting. The great dread of creative writing professors? “Their eyes met... over the keg...” Laughter.  14.

dialogues.speaker: EARNEST STUDENT
dialogues.text: I just want my narrator to be funny and smart, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know. You want your narrator to be funny and smart. Here’s a tip, then: Have him say funny, smart things some of the time. Laughter. Lipsky jots down a note.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You did a good job. Who’s next? Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David walk down the hall after class.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m usually a much better teacher than this. I swear to God.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I thought you were great. They obviously love you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, you know they do.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David park and go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They give their order to the WAITER.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: ..-And what can I get you to drink? Beer, Or...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uh, not for me, thanks. A large Diet Rite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I‘ll have the same.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I'll be right back with your pop. The waiter goes. Lipsky sets up the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You don’t drink. David doesn’t answer right away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that a question?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: It’s an observation.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ah. I see. No; I do not drink. You can order whatever you want, go right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That’s all right. My friends who have been through the program say they didn't want people to drink in front of them, so out of respect...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm not any sort of authority on any sort of “program.” But from my very limited outside understanding, people who have been in it for a while: you could snort cocaine off the back of your hand and they’re okay. Lipsky is embarrassed for having been presumptuous.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know what I would love to do?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I would love to do a profile of one of you guys who’s doin’ a profile of me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That is interesting... 15. Pause.  16.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Too po-mo and cute?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Maybe, for Rolling Stone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But it would be interesting. (A beat.) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's just, you’re gonna go back to New York and sit at your desk and shape this thing however you want. And that to me is extremely disturbing.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why is it disturbing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I would like to shape the impression of me that’s coming across. I can’t even tell if I like you yet ‘cause I’m too worried whether you like me. Before Lipsky can assure him, the waiter brings their sod

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (handing off the sodas) Here you go. Your food will be out soon. Can I get you anything else?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: We’re fine, thanks. The waiter goes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So what's this piece about? What does “Jann” want?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What’s it like being the most-talked about writer in the country. That sort of thing. That sounds so -- Lipsky seems embarrassed as soon as he says the words.  17.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How do you learn to do this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Interviewing. Did you go to interviewing school?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No... I, uh... A beat. Lipsky feels a tad fraudulent to identify himself a writer to the man whose success and talent he envies.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I'm a writer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I mean I write fiction. Just published my first novel, as a matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What’s it called?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: The Art Fair? David shrugs. He’s never heard of it. Lipsky feels foolis for having brought it up.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: And I, uh, had a collection published, a couple of years ago. Lipsky’s pumping leg betrays his anxiety. David notices.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You're a nervous guy, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No no I’m okay. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I’m terrified.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Are you? I think it’s going to be a lot of fun.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The food is decimated. David is loosening up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The thing about this tour is... I would like to get laid out of ita couple of times, but... Like, people come up, they kinda slither up during readings or whatever. But it seems like, what I want is not to have to take any action.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Like...?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Like, I don’t want to have to say, “Would you like to come back to my hotel?” I want them to say, “I am coming back to the hotel. Where is your hotel?” Lipsky laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t stand to look like I’m actively trading on this sexually. Which of course I would be happy to do. In retrospect, it was lucky that I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Basically, it just would have made me feel lonely.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why lonely?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because it wouldn’t have had anything to do with me, it would have just been...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Your fame?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. Whatever.  34 19.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You're famous. You can say that. Except... if they’re responding to your work, and the work is so personal... then trading on it is actually another way of meeting you, isn’t that right? A beat. David is impressed by Lipsky’s analysis.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That is so good.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This piece’ll really be good if it’s mostly you. Talk all you want, man, save me a whole lotta trouble. Lipsky laughs, sensing his stock has risen, relaxing more into the rhythm of their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/COMMERCIAL DRAG
dialogues.text: David at the wheel, driving Lipsky’s rental. Lights from fast-food restaurant signs light up their faces. Tape running.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So this is what a real car feels like. The one I have is like riding a power lawn mower.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You think being handsome has anything to do with your success?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (incredulously) What?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You are photogenic... You look good in your author’s photo.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You'd have to come put me down if I even start thinking that way.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Thinking what way? About how books are sold?  35 20.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Like, “Do you want to do a Rolling Stone interview, do you want to do xX, do you want to do Y” worries me that what I’m doing right now is being a whore.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: A whore? Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know, cashing in somehow, or getting some little celebrity for myself. That will, from some bizarre set of misunderstandings, sell more copies of the book.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can quote that. Preferably ina context where I don’t sound like a total dweeb. (A beat.) By the way, are they gonna send Annie Leibovitz to take pictures?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. Possibly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know: You’re a good-looking guy. We should have ‘em photograph you, and say you're me. Maybe I’1l finally end up getting laid. Lipsky laughs.

dialogues.speaker: 7-ELEVEN
dialogues.text: In the blue-white fluorescent light, David and Lipsky ad-lib while stocking up on six-packs of Diet Rite, chewi tobacco, Oreos, etc. At the cash register, Lipsky prepares to pay.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Let me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don’t have to pay for my shit.  36 37 21.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: It’s not coming out of my pocket... I've got an expense account.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All right, if you insist... David goes back for more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riding through town, the Davids are eating candy like teenagers on a joyride.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If you ate this stuff all the time, what would be wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Except for your teeth falling out and getting really fat?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, it doesn’t have any of the nourishment of real food, but it’s real pleasurable masticating and swallowing this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Like seductive commercial entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Exactly, and what saves us is that most commercial entertainment isn’t very good.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What about good seductive commercial entertainment - like Die Hard?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The first Die Hard? Great film.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Brilliant, right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The best. EXT. DAVID’S HOUSE - 1996 - NIGHT 37 The car pulls up, parks. They get out with the spoils fro the 7-Eleven. Mid-discourse:  38 22.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So if the book’s about anything, it’s about the question of: Why am I watching all this shit? It’s not about the shit, it’s about me. Why am I doing it? And what’s so American about what I’m doing? We hear the dogs barking as David unlocks the door and th enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs run out to do their thing. David puts away the s and snacks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The minute I start talking about this stuff, it sounds, number one: very vague. And, two: really reductive.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’re being reductive or vague at all.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because it’s like, I don’t have a diagnosis, a system of prescriptions. You know? Like, why are we - and by “we” I mean people like you and me: mostly white, upper middle class, obscenely well-educated, doing really interesting jobs, sitting in really expensive chairs, watching the best, most sophisticated electronic equipment money can buy - why do we feel empty and unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Kinda like Hamlet. With channel- surfing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m not saying TV is bad or a waste of your time. Any more than, you know, Masturbation is bad or a waste of your time. It's a pleasurable way to spend a few minutes. But if you're doing it twenty times a day, if your primary sexual relationship is with your own hand, then there's something wrong.  Silence. 23.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: At least with masturbation, some action has been performed, though, right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All right, you could make me look like a real dick if you print this: Yes, you're performing muscular movements with your hand as you're jerking off. But what you're doing is running a movie in your head, and having a fantasy relationship with somebody who isn't real, in order to stimulate a purely neurological response. Look: as the Internet grows in the next ten, fifteen years, and virtual reality pornography becomes a reality, we're gonna have to develop some machinery, inside our guts, to help us turn off pure, unalloyed pleasure. Otherwise, I don’t know about you, but I’m gonna have to leave the planet.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (smiles uncertainly) Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because the technology is just gonna get better and better. And it's gonna get easier and easier, and more and more convenient, and more and more pleasurable, to be alone with images on a screen, given to us by people who do not love us but want our money. Which is fine. In low doses. But if that's the basic main staple of your diet? You're gonna die. Ina meaningful way, you're going to die. Lipsky mulls over the gravity of what David has said. David breaks the portentous silence when he pops a of tobacco in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Can I try that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Be my guest. It takes some getting used to. Lipsky tries it and makes a horrible face. David laughs.  39 40 24.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You mind if I use your uh... Amused, David points the way to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I believe it’s unoccupied. Lipsky goes, leaving the tape running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky spits the tobacco into the sink. He cups his hands under the running water and rinses his mouth. He looks at himself in the mirror and takes a deep, fortifying breath He stealthily opens the medicine cabinet and finds it sto with jars of vitamins, Stri-Dex pads and tubes of Topol, toothpaste for smokers. He jots down notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky returns, looks around. David is playing with his dogs.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Do you not have a TV?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I do not have a TV.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Cause if I had a TV, I'd watch it all the time. I don’t even know if I would watch it; it would be on all the time - my version of a fireplace. A source of warmth and light in the corner that I would occasionally get sucked into.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Did you watch a lot of T.V. when you were a kid?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. A lot. You?  25.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Me? Yeah, I did. I moved in with a woman who grew up without a television, and living with her, the first month was torture, and then I realized it was probably the best thing for me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you guys stay together?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: It’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I was seeing this woman, then she moved to L.A. and we theoretically broke up. And I started seeing this other woman, but then I started seeing the first woman again - trying the bi- coastal thing - and the second... Well, let’s just say she hasn’t taken it very well.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s so much easier having dogs. You don’t get laid; but you also don’t get the feeling you’re hurting their feelings all the time. I emphasize: strictly platonic relationship with the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You're not dating anyone?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Seriously dating? No. I’m out of practice; I wouldn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You want to have kids?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think someday I do; do you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Eventually. I think.  26.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Writing books is kinda like raising children, but you gotta be careful: you should take pride in the work but it’s bad to want that glory to reflect back on you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You worry about having children? David seems far away; this is difficult for him. After a beat, he speaks, sounding vulnerable, which doesn’t go unnoticed by Lipsky.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know that I want to say anything more about it - okay?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (prepared to back off) That’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I mean, we can joke about getting laid on tour and stuff, but...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I just thought, it’d be nice to have someone to be sharing all this wonderful stuff with.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. I really have wished I was married, the last couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, because nobody quite gets it. Your friends who aren't in the writing biz are all just awed by your picture in Time, and your agent and editor are good people, but they have their own agendas. It’s fun talking to you about it, but you've got an agenda, too, and a set of interests that diverges from mine.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That’s true...  27.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There’s something nice about having somebody who kinda shared your life, and that you could allow yourself just to be happy and confused with.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Somebody you can call when you get back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uh huh. (A beat.) So, why aren’t you married at thirty?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why aren't you married at thirty-four?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay. Um... I think it's hard to cast that role .. to fill it when you know it's for thirty or forty years .. someone who, whatever mental landscape you're in, they're going to be in it too, you need someone who'll fit any landscape you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I can't put it as well as you did about the “mental landscapes,” I just know I'm hard to be around. David's “mental landscapes” reference: competitive, fawni mocking? Lipsky isn’t sure.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because when I want to be by myself, like to work, I really want to be by myself. I think if you dedicate yourself to anything, one facet of that is that it makes you very very self-conscious. You end up using people. Wanting them around when you want them around, but then sending them away.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Comes with the territory, though, doesn’t it? Self-consciousness?  28.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There’s good self-consciousness. And then there’s this toxic, paralyzing, raped-by-psychic-Bedouins self- consciousness. Lipsky laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (re: Alanis poster) Can you do me a favor? Can you tell me about that poster over there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Alanis? I don’t know, I guess I'm susceptible like everybody else. Why?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: She's pretty, alright...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, but in a very sloppy, very human way. That squeaky, orgasmic quality in her voice? Here’s what it is: A lot of women in magazines are pretty in a way that isn’t erotic because they don’t look like anybody you know.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can’t imagine them putting a quarter in a parking meter or eating a bologna sandwich. But her, I don't know, I just find her absolutely riveting.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: How'd you get to know her, her music, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listening to cheesy Bloomington radio, and “I Want to Tell You” came on.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (correcting him) “You Oughta Know.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?  29.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: “I Want to Tell You” is the book 0.J. Simpson wrote.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be great if O.J. Simpson sang “You Oughta Know” and Alanis Morissette wrote a book about not killing two people? They laugh. Lipsky is pleased to make David laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If somehow this whole fuss could get me even like a five-minute cup of tea with her...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you put out feelers, see if she'd be willing to meet you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You serious? I would never do that.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'd be too terrified. Why, you would do that?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: If I were you? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A date with Alanis Morissette? What would I say to her? “Hello, Miss Morissette. What is it like to be you?” (gruff voice) “I don’t know -— shut up. And get the fuck away from me.”

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: But you’d go if she called? “Hey, Dave. I’m at the Drake in Chicago. Let’s have that tea.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah... except this is gonna look ridiculous: like I’m using Rolling Stone as a vehicle to, like -  30.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: It’s been used for worse.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, I would do it. I’d go ina heartbeat. As Lipsky cracks up, David paints the picture:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Perspiring heavily, all the way up there, shoving Certs into my mouth. Goin’ nuts. It would cost me like a week of absolute trauma. But yeah, I would do it in a heartbeat. David realizes the late hour.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I like... I like talking to you but we have to get up real early.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What is it, like ten o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s eleven-thirty, dickbrain.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Shit...I am so sorry, I completely lost track of time. When should I pick you up in the morning? Lipsky gets his coat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Motel. There was like a Days Inn on the main road. I thought I’d -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (overlap) No no you don’t want to stay there - trust me. I’ve gota guest-roomish place you can crash in.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You sure? I don’t want to impose... 41 INT. DAVID’S HOUSE/GUEST ROOM - 1996 - NIGHT 41 The room is cluttered, not unlike Lipsky’s place in New Y David clears stuff off a futon that’s on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let me get this shit out of the way... Hm. (re: the rumpled sheet) Might be a good idea to change that. Together, they put on a clean sheet. When they’re done:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uh, leave the door open for the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They like to wander from room to room during the night; if the door’s closed, they'll eat it to get through if they have to. ‘Night. Lipsky makes a move to shake his host’s hand but doesn’t. David goes. Lipsky finds himself surrounded by intimidati stacks of domestic and foreign editions of David's books. INT. DAVID’S HOUSE/GUEST ROOM - 1996 - LATER 41A Lipsky is in bed. From his POV on the floor: The looming towers of Infinite Jest. The door creaks open: Drone and Jeeves pay a visit. EXT. DAVID’S HOUSE - 1996 - DAWN 43 In the middle of a wintry field. INT. DAVID'S HOUSE/KITCHEN - 1996 — DAWN 44 Lipsky, wrecked, enters and finds David drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Morning. There’s coffee...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I don’t need caffeine to wake up. But cigarettes...? He lights up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Brothers of the lung. A Pop-Tart pops up from the toaster.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Want to split this with me? It’s the last one I’ve got.  46 47 32.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No thanks. David splits it in two and offers Lipsky half.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mi Pop-Tart es su Pop-Tart.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Thanks. They bite into their Pop-Tarts. EXT. DAVID’S HOUSE - 1996 - MOMENTS LATER 46 A miserable morning. Grey, freezing rain. Lipsky scrapes ice off the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/OUTSKIRTS
dialogues.text: Windshield wipers clear falling sleet. The tape recorder the transmission between them. Radio plays softly. Riding past farmland, plants, strip malls. David, in the passeng seat, gives the lay of the land.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ..-There’s a Mitsubishi plant, and then there’s a lot of farm-support stuff, like Ro-Tech, Anderson Seeds...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? I mean, why aren’t you in New York?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Every time I go to New York, I get caught up in this - there’s this enormous hiss of egos at various stages of inflation and deflation. It’s me-me-me. Lipsky takes out his tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: So, I gotta ask: What’s with the bandanna?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: People think it’s a way you’re trying to connect with the younger reading audience.  33.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that what people think? I don’t know many Gen-Xers who wear ‘em. Jeez. I don’t know what to say. I guess I wish you hadn’t brought this up.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because now I’m worrying that it’s going to seem intentional. Like if I don't wear it, am I not wearing it because I’m bowing to other people’s perception that it’s a commercial choice? Or do I do what I want, even though it’s perceived as commercial -— and it’s just like one more crazy circle to go around.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Sorry. When did you start wearing them?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: In Tuscon. It was a hundred degrees all the time. I would perspire so much... I would drip into the electric typewriter, I was nervous I was gonna give myself a shock. And then I discovered that I felt better with them on.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know it’s a security blanket for me - whenever I’m nervous. Or feel like I have to keep myself together. It makes me feel kinda creepy that people view it as an affectation or a trademark or something. It’s more of a foible, the recognition of a weakness, that I’m kinda afraid my head’s gonna explode. Lipsky laughs.  51 34.

dialogues.speaker: I./E. CAR/OUTSKIRTS
dialogues.text: The Grand Am on the highway to O’Hare. Trucks race past spewing cascades of water. Wipers at top speed. Ambient Tape running. Lipsky at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Your parents are both academics?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My dad, philosophy; my mom, English. You?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Me? My dad’s in advertising, my mom’s a painter. When they split up, I lived with my mother in SoHo and my brother moved in with my dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sounds like there’s a story there.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: There is; I just wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So what was that like, your family divided that way?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey, who’s interviewing whom? How old were you when you started writing fiction?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Twenty-one?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Never before?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think I started a World War Two novel when I was nine.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A bunch of people with strangely hyperdeveloped skills and powers, who are going to invade Hitler's bunker. Then, in college, I wrote a couple of papers for other people.  52 53

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: They were paying you to write their papers?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't put it that coarsely. But let's say there were complicated systems of reward. I’d read two or three of their papers to learn, you know, what their music sounded like. And I remember thinking, “Man, I'm really good at this. I'm a weird kind of forger. I mean, I can sound kind of like anybody.”

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Odds are I’m gonna want to talk to your parents.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Biographical stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I hereby request that you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They're real private people, and I would have a hard time with it. So, no you may not.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (backing off) Okay. I may not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky looks for a place to park the Grand Am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Davids check in at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peanuts, pretzels and drinks sit on their open tray table  36.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Crap jobs? Let’s see: I was a security guard for this software company for three and a half months.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I had to wear this polyester uniform, and walk under these fluorescent lights, twirlin’ my baton, checking in every ten minutes: [mimes a walkie- talkie] “All clear at this cubicle!” Like, every bad '60s novel about meaningless authority.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: And were you thinking, “My God, I had two books come out when I was in my early twenties and here I am...”?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. As a matter of fact, one reason I liked that job is, I walked around not thinking. In a really like, “Huh: there's a ceiling tile.”

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: And after the security guard thing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This is the worst: I worked as a towel boy at this chichi health club.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: A “towel boy?”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They called me something other than a towel boy, but I was in effect a towel boy. Who every once in a while was entrusted with the job of checking people in, having them show their i.d?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'm sitting there, and who should walk in to get their towel, but this guy, this writer I knew.  37. Who received a Whiting Writer's Award the same year I had, like two years earlier.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So I see this guy that I'd been up on this fucking rostrum with, having Eudora Welty give us this prize -

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: - And two years later, I'm like .. It's the only time I've literally dived under something, to have somebody avoid seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Did you think you were done then?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was pretty sure life was over.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: This is after your suicide watch? David blinks. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How’d you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I read it somewhere. McLean's, right? How long were you there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Eight days, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why were you there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mostly 'cause I was scared I would do something stupid. I had a friend from high school who tried to kill himself by sitting in a garage with the car runnin'. And what it turned out was, he didn't die, but it really fucked up his brain.  38. And I knew, that if anybody was fated to fuck up a suicide attempt, it was me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: So there you are still in your twenties...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My late twenties.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Your late twenties, somewhat in pain about your desire to become a sort of successful literary person.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think probably the not very sophisticated diagnosis is that I was depressed. 'Cause by this time, my ego's all invested in the writing. It's the only thing that I've gotten, you know, food pellets from the universe for. So I felt really trapped: Like, “Uh-oh, my five years is up. I've gotta move on, but I don't want to move on.” I was really stuck. And drinking was part of that. But it wasn't that I was stuck because I drank. It was like, I really sort of felt like my life was over at twenty- eight. And that felt really bad, and I didn't wanna feel it. So I would do all kinds of things: I mean, I would drink real heavy, I would like fuck strangers. Oh, God -- Or, then, for two weeks I wouldn't drink, and I'd run ten miles every morning, in a desperate, like very American, “I will fix this somehow, by taking radical action” sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: And here you are, promoting this acclaimed book. Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: David. This [the interview] is nice. This is not real. They look at one another.  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys walk toward baggage claim.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: An escort’s supposed to pick me up and, you know, escort me to the reading. Of course, when I hear “escort,” I imagine like full geisha with hairpins who will take you to the bookstore, then back to the hotel, walk on your back and fuck your eyeballs out. Lipsky is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I think that’s her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ah. Just as I pictured. At the end of a long corridor stands a solidly-built, per forty-ish woman, PATTY, holding a sign: “MR. WALLACE.”

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Mr. Wallace! I recognized you from your photograph! I’m Patty Gundersson! Welcome to Minneapolis!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you, Patty.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m David Lipsky.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: David and David. That’s easy. It’s the Twin Cities, so...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (in explanation) We only just met. He’s writing a piece on the tour. Should we get going?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Yes, come on, come on... As they exit:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How was your morning, Patty...  40.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Good. How about you guys? The flight alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving through Minneapolis. David and Lipsky share the backseat. Patty is a talker.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: You wouldn't believe all the famous people I’ve driven around! Shirley MacLaine? When she came through on a book tour? Ron Wood. You know, of the Rolling Stones?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Of course, yeah, wow.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Peter O'Toole... Very thin, but delightful. Lipsky sees the passing, obstructed view of the Mary Tyle Moore commemorative statue.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, look: The Mary Tyler Moore statue.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Do you want me to stop?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Everybody who comes here, the first thing they want to see is “where did Mary Tyler Moore throw her cap in the air?” One of our biggest attractions. You sure you don’t want me to stop?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sure. Thanks, anyway. (sotto, to Lipsky) Trust me: This is about as sexy as the tour gets. Lipsky laughs.  61 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David check in at the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Lipsky. L-I-P, S-K-Y.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: I’ve got you in a standard double. And Mr. Wallace? You have a room with twins.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ah, yes: Anita and Consuela. Lipsky laughs. The desk clerk doesn’t get the joke.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator arrives with a ding. They both get off; Davi finds his room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: See ya later. I’m gonna take a nap. We follow Lipsky in the opposite direction to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hair still wet from a shower, Lipsky is on the phone Bob, his increasingly exasperated editor.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) Well, what does he have to say about the heroin rumors?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I haven’t gotten to that.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to say: Is it true you were a heroin addict?

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s your story.  64 42.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s hard.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Why? Because you like him?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Well... Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: David. You’ve got to press him.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOB'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Be a prick if you have to. You’re not his best buddy, you’re a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I know. Right. Bye. He hangs up and looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: E/I. HUNGRY MIND BOOKSTORE
dialogues.text: A cool, independent bookstore [now defunct]. Patty escort the Davids in. People who have begun to show up for the e recognize David; some gawk, some smile. David's friends, attractive women around his age, JULIE (petite, brunette) BETSY (tall, striking), surprise him with their attendanc

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you guys showed up!

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: We wouldn’t miss this, are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Gluttons for punishment, both of you. They greet and hug David. Introductions, handshakes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This is David Lipsky. A reporter from Rolling Stone.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Oh, wow, hi.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This is Julie...  43.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hi, Julie.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And this is Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Betsy and I went to grad school together, in Tucson.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Nice. (to Julie) How do you know David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: She wrote me a fan letter.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I did, I was the books editor at City Pages and I wrote him a fan letter, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Julie has worked with a whole lot of writers -

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: So I’m discriminating.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Exactly. And we discovered that we actually kind of like each other as people.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s how I met Jon Franzen: I wrote him a fan letter. Writers are pushovers when it comes to flattery. You could try it sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room, crammed with books and an old sofa, doubles as kind of “green room” for visiting writers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA CAVENAUGH, the shop manager, a robust earth-mother loves books and her job, offers cookies to Julie, Betsy, Lipsky and Patty while David looks over his reading selection.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You sure I can’t get you something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you have any artificial spit? Everyone laughs, perhaps a little too heartily.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, it’s an actual pharmaceutical product. Zero-Lube.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Really? Artificial saliva?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s way better ‘cause it lubricates. You don’t get that clicky sound you do with dry mouth. He demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I‘ll have to remember that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Next tour, I bring a case.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: In the meantime, what can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Water? No ice? Martha goes to fetch it. Lipsky and Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Are you a fiction writer, too?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: I’m a poet, actually.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, wow.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Just got my first poem published in the Kenyon Review.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Really! Wow! Congratulations! David observes Lipsky chatting animatedly with Betsy, disapproval registering on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha leads them to the side of the podium. On the move:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to be a prima donna, but I'd really prefer it if we didn’t have aQéA.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Of course. Whatever you feel most comfortable with.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s always stuff like “Where do you get your ideas?” (to Lipsky) From a Time-Life subscription series for $17.95 a month. Lipsky and Martha laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It’s show time! Martha goes to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Lipsky) It’s all downhill from here.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: This is the very last stop on his book tour and we’re very lucky to have him! Ladies and gentlemen... Would you welcome to the Hungry Mind... David. Foster. Wallace! The packed audience applauds enthusiastically. Lipsky watches as David approaches the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of excited book buyers wait their turn. Seate at a table, David signs one and hands it to a YOUNG WOMAN  46.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There you go. The young woman looks at it with bemusement.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: What is that supposed to be, a computer?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What? No. It’s a smiley face. See?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Ohhh...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If you want, I could put Wite-Out over it...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You sure? It’s your book... Lipsky, in ad-libbed conversation with Betsy and Julie, observes from the sidelines. Back to David. A NERDY GUY pulls out the Vintage paperbac copy of The Broom of the System.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh no. That old thing?

dialogues.speaker: NERDY GUY
dialogues.text: Do you mind...?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Eh, the new one’s better. The guy plunks down a copy of Infinite Jest, too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Now we're talkin’. The guy laughs as David sees Lipsky laughing with Julie a Betsy and is threatened by it. Lipsky sees David looking them and smiles; David ominously doesn’t return the smile He turns instead to the next customer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who’s next?  67 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Lipsky are dining out on pancakes with Julie an Betsy. Laid-back, improvisational. It’s toward the end of the meal.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I couldn't be plain old “Dave Wallace” ‘cause there were “Dave Wallaces” all over the place. And “David Raines Wallace” wrote for The New Yorker. That’s when Fred Hill asked me what my middle name was and decided that was what my name was gonna be.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: This is literally the worst superhero origin story.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I didn’t claim it was an origin story...

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Dave, remember in Tucson, that professor you kind of locked horns with?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My nemesis who shall remain nameless? I think I was kind of a prick. But so was he. I was just unteachable. I mean, I don't think I was actively unpleasant in class.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: You were pretty unpleasant. Well, I loved it. (to Lipsky) He was pleasantly unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve got to get up unconscionably early for this public radio interview, so we'd better...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Which means that I have to get up early, too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can do whatever the fuck you want. Sleep in if you want to. David's mercurial attitude toward him unnerves Lipsky.  68 48.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: We'll get you back to the hotel. They settle up the check.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I will get the check. This one is on me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, it’s on Jann.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: “Jann?”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jann is his boss.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Rolling Stone.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. JULIE'S CAR/DOWNTOWN SKYLINE
dialogues.text: Julie at the wheel; Betsy in the passenger seat. David an Lipsky are in the backseat smoking, each blowing smoke ou their respective windows. Spirits high, they sing along w the Alanis Morissette song “You Oughta Know” on the radio

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Can you close the windows, pleaaasssse, it’s fucking freezing!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh but this is our hypothermia smoking tour of the Midwest. Julie and Betsy laugh. David does not.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: “Hypothermia smoking tour.” I love that!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Sounds like something Dave would say.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to himself) Doesn't it. David doesn’t like that Lipsky amused his friends with a like joke - and Lipsky senses tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie’s car pulls up and deposits the Davids.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing tomorrow after your interview?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don’t know yet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Give us a call, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: We're here. Ad-libbed “Good night”s all around. Julie and Betsy drive away and David and Lipsky enter the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That was nice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: still?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA pans M n M’s and candy wrappers: The detritus of a alcoholic mini-bar snack attack.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: How does that feel? People fighting to get in, big line of people who want to impress you... We find David and Lipsky in twin beds, facing each other, talking like college roommates pulling an all-nighter.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'll tell you - having an audience with really really pretty girls who are paying attention to you, and like what you’re sayin’? Is gratifying on a fairly I think simple mammal level.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I know. Why is that?  71 A beat. 50.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think pretty girls are what we most sort of dream and despair of ever having, of ever paying attention to you. And there they are, in the front row, making eyes at you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I think my girlfriend is in love you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No she’s not.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I think she is. I think she likes your writing more than she likes mine. It’s getting kind of annoying.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Get her on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No, she’s probably sleeping anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Lipsky holds the phone. We HEAR Sarah’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over the phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hi! How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: It's fine. Did I wake you up?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No, I’m up reading Infinite Jest. It's pretty amazing.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Good. Listen: Somebody wants to say hello. Hold on a sec.  72 51. He hands the receiver to David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (whispers to Lipsky) What’s her name again?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Sarah. David speaks into the phone. (When David is on the phone, - and Lipsky - hear only his side of the conversation.)

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sarah? Hi. It’s Dave Wallace. Lipsky tries to reclaim the phone a couple of times durin the following but David, engaged in a power play, retains control: his way of re-asserting himself after Lipsky’s perceived transgressions with David’s women friends.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you telephonically, too. Let me ask him. (to Lipsky) Are you behaving yourself?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: She's asking that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Sarah) I’m reasonably sure he is. I don’t have eyes on him 24/7. Lipsky reaches for the phone but David continues talking.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’re you up to tonight? Oh, wow. You're kidding me. Oh my gosh. What part are you up to? Wow, you’re really far along! Oh, thank you. That's very flattering. Now that David’s talking about the book, Lipsky gives up frustration, plops into a chair, and quietly seethes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky, in bed, is on the phone with Sarah. He’s livid.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What the fuck was that about?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) What.  73 74 75 52.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You were on the phone with him for like a half hour!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a half hour...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: It was! It was twenty-five minutes; I timed it! You were only supposed to say hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — MORNING Lipsky leaves his room and goes down the hall to collect David. He knocks on his door. Listens. TV sounds from inside. Knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: David? Escort’s waiting. We gotta go. David, still in boxers and Chicago Cubs t-shirt, frazzled opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sorry, man. Got totally lost in an orgy of crap. David ducks into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A simultaneous broadcast of Falcon Crest, Magnum P.I., and Charlie's Angels: A perfect storm of shit. Out in a minute. We hear the shower running. Lipsky sits on the bed watchi Jaclyn Smith and Farrah Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David, with his shower-wet hair pinned up, fin Patty’s car out front. They get in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: You're wearing that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: For a radio interview? Yes. Her disapproval showing, she pulls away. 75  76

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A pretty PRODUCTION ASSISTANT greets David and Lipsky.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi. Dave. Dave Wallace. P.A. (blushes ) I know who you are. David introduces Lipsky.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My amanuensis, Mr. Boswell. The P.A. shakes Lipsky’s hand, playing along with the jok P.A. (in greeting) “Mr. Boswell.” Right this way. She leads David, followed by Lipsky, down a corridor past glass-walled studios. Lipsky sees people recognize David, whisper among themselves. Young women smile shyly, excite to be in the presence of a cool celebrity. P.A. We record digitally. I hope that’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So only yes or no answers? She rolls her eyes. Lipsky laughs, David sees him scribbl in his pad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If you do a really mean job, I have twenty years to get you back. Remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interview goes on the air. Lipsky observes from outsi the booth. The NPR GUY has a good radio voice.

dialogues.speaker: NPR GUY
dialogues.text: My guest today is David Foster Wallace, who has burst on the literary scene with his 1,079-page, three-pound- three-ounce novel, Infinite Jest.  54. Jay McInerney called it “something like a sleek Vonnegut chassis wrapped in layers of post-millennial Zola.” David Foster Wallace, welcome to our show.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you, glad to be here. He exchanges looks with Lipsky outside the booth.

dialogues.speaker: NPR GUY
dialogues.text: You have said that you saw yourself as - quote - “a combination of being incredibly shy, and being an egomaniac, too.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think I said “exhibitionist, also.”

dialogues.speaker: NPR GUY
dialogues.text: Meaning? David glances at Lipsky.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I think being shy basically means being self-absorbed to the extent that it makes it difficult to be around other people.

dialogues.speaker: NPR GUY
dialogues.text: Difficult for you, or difficult for the other people?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I suppose a little bit of both.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Patty waits outside her car as the Davids join her.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: That was wonderful! I listened to the whole show! So interesting! I may have to buy your book and read it!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. David and Lipsky climb in.  79 80 55.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: So, you have the rest of the day free. Where would you like to go?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you know where the Mall of America is?

dialogues.speaker: E./I. MALL OF AMERICA/VARIOUS SHOPS
dialogues.text: They discover the vast courts at each corner of the mall. They walk through the amusement park; ride a roller coast ride a carousel. In a mirror maze, they make their way through, trying not to bump into the walls. They try flig simulators, play mini-golf, and walk through the underwat tunnels of the aquarium. They stare blankly at Build-a-Be bear parts which stare blankly back at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Lipsky sit over lunch, the recorder running on table between them. They watch SHOPPERS.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I wanted to write something that had kind of the texture of what life was like in America right now: This enormous tsunami of stuff comin’ at you. And also - it’s not unfun.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Not at all. It is sort of heavy, though. I mean weight-wise.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My friend said when it hit the porch, it sounded like a car bomb going off.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Who are your readers? College kids?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The people who seem most enthusiastic are young men. Which I guess I can understand - it’s a fairly male book, a fairly nerdy book, about loneliness. You can expect that somebody who's willing to read and read hard a thousand-page book is gonna be somebody with some loneliness issues.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You think it’s about loneliness?  56.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think if there is sort of a sadness for people under forty-five or something, it has to do with pleasure and achievement and entertainment. And a kind of emptiness at heart of what they thought was going on, that maybe I can hope that parts of the book will speak to their nerve endings a little bit. He presses stop on the tape recorder, surprising Lipsky.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, if you quote any of this, you'd do me a favor if you’d say that I’m talking about what I hope for the book, or what the book is tryin’ to do, I don’t pretend that it has. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That’s fine. Lipsky presses play.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: So: the Walter Kirn review, in New York Magazine -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Didn’t read it. I mean, I heard.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: “Next year’s book awards have been decided” kind of thing? How’d it feel?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I applauded his taste and discernment. What do you want me to say? How would you feel about it?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: How would I feel? That I’d known all along it was good, and here was someone validating that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All I know is, this is absolutely the best I could do between like 1992 and 1995. And if everybody hated it, I wouldn’t be thrilled, but I don’t think I'd be devastated, either.  57. It’s like, if you’re used to doing heavy-duty literary stuff that doesn’t sell well, being human animals with egos, we find a way to accommodate that fact by the following equation: If it sells really well and gets a lot of attention, it must be shit. Then, of course, the ultimate irony is: if your thing gets a lot of attention and sells really well, then the very mechanism you’ve used to shore yourself up when your stuff didn’t sell well is now part of the Darkness Nexus when it does, so you’re screwed. You can’t win. Lipsky is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Lipsky stand outside. Julie and Betsy arrive. A libbed greetings all around.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, this place is insane!

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe we actually found you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome look over movie titles on the electronic boa

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: What’s The Juror?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Demi Moore. John Grisham.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Happy Gilmore?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
