dialogues.text: No, that’s Adam Sandler.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ooo, Broken Arrow! Perfect dumb boy movie. Things that blow up!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I’ve already seen it, but...  82 83 84 58.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You've already seen it? Boy, you are aman from my own heart, aren’t you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t mind, I'll see it again...

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: I'll see anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We can see something else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud, explosive action scene from Broken Arrow with Joh Travolta and Christian Slater fills the screen. Seated up close, their heads craned looking up at the scr Julie and Betsy sit together and Lipsky monitors David's reactions. David is an ideal spectator, totally engaged w a child-like guilelessness that Lipsky finds endearing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh boy... oh wow, oh jeez...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, Betsy, David and Lipsky file out after the movie. Improv post-movie discussion.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wasn’t that a cool shot at the end, when Travolta gets impaled by the thing?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you have a T.V.?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Uh huh. I do.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: On TV: John Michael Higgins in The Late Shift. They sit around snacking on fresh popcorn and soda.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know that guy.  59.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: The guy playing Leno?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, the guy playing Letterman.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: How do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Went to Amherst with him.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I hated his guts. Laughter. Lipsky gets up to go to the kitchen which is visible from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Does anyone want drinks or anything?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (calls) There’s also beer.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Soda’s fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: (to David) Why did you hate him?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He was just very cool and popular and I was not, that was the basic offense. Betsy gets something out of her bag and joins Lipsky in t kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: I brought you something.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You brought me something? She gives him a copy of the Kenyon Review.  60.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Oh, great! This has your poem in it! Thank you! In the living room, David shows Julie the TV listings.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look what's on next. Algiers. Starring Hedy Lamarr. Have you seen it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: Uh, no.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s one of the greats. And Hedy Lamarr is fascinating. She invented frequency hopping. David sees Lipsky and Betsy talking and doesn’t like it. Back to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey, when I get back to New York, you mind if I e-mailed you with questions about what Dave was like in grad school and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Sure, if it’s okay with Dave.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’s fine with Dave. Can I have your e-mail address?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Sure. She looks for something to write on, scribbles her addres and gives it to Lipsky before going back to the living ro A moment later, David gets up, walks over to Lipsky, and backs him up against the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (whispers ) What are you doing? Lipsky initially thinks David is joking.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (smiling) What?  61.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I saw you hitting on Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hitting on...? I was talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: David, I saw you! You got her to give you her address.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Her e-mail address. In case I had questions, about the piece I am writing about you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t want her talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Fine! I won’t contact her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I told you she and I dated when we were in grad school... The least you can do is show me the respect of not coming on to her right in front of me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Dave, I’m sorry if it looked that way. That was not my intention. Besides, why would I want to get involved with somebody who lives in St. Paul?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You're already involved with somebody who lives in Los Angeles... David is glaring at him when we hear:

dialogues.speaker: JULIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (calls) Everything’s fine. Thank you. (to Lipsky) Just stay away from her. Okay? Bea good guy. David goes back to the women.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What'd I miss?  86 87

dialogues.speaker: 87A
dialogues.text: 88 89 90 62. Once he catches his breath, Lipsky, breaking solidarity w David's abstinence, gets a beer out of the fridge and pointedly, while making eye contact with David, pops open can and defiantly takes a slug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Algiers is on television. David watches; Betsy is gone; Julie has fallen asleep. Lipsky, now wary of David, sits some distance away, struggling to stay awake.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. TAXI/DOWNTOWN
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David ride in the backseat in silence, avoidin each other, looking out their respective windows.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The cab pulls up to their hotel. Lipsky is prepared to pa the fare.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That’s all right, my expense account’'1l cover it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So will mine. I got it, I said. Lipsky relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David ride up in silence. The elevator arrives their floor with a ding. INT. HOTEL WHITNEY/CORRIDOR - MINNEAPOLIS - 1996 -— CONTI Lipsky goes in one direction; David in the other.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey. Good night. David doesn’t respond. Lipsky watches him petulantly go d the hall to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky, agitated, paces while talking on the phone.  91 63.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) Were you flirting?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No! Sarah, I swear to you: He just completely went bonkers on me.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You do that, David, you know? You’re not even aware of it.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You're compulsively flirtatious.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you're taking his side!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I am not!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yes you are. Listen, I think I’m just really tired. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: David? David...? He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. HOTEL WHITNEY/VALET AREA
dialogues.text: Lipsky and David, unsmiling, emerge from the hotel with t bags. Patty greets them with a cheery smile.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Good morning! And how are we this morning? David climbs into the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I think I’1l ride up front. David looks a little surprised but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. Here, let me get my junk out of the way...  92 93 94 64. She makes room for Lipsky who gets into the passenger sea Patty continues yammering but Lipsky tunes her out. The c pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-flight. David, his beaten-up Robert Heinlein paperbac on his lap, sleeps soundly with his lips slightly parted his bandanna’d head leaning against the window. Lipsky studies his sunlit face with new objectivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fresh layer of snow covers every car in the lot, making them indistinguishable from one another. David and Lipsky walk through the rows of cars, David carrying his knapsac They continue to walk up and down the rows of cars lookin for the Grand Am. Lipsky repeatedly clicks his key hoping have the car announce itself with blinking headlights. Lipsky clicks the key and locates the car. Finally. They throw their bags in the trunk and start to get in.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You didn’t think to write down where we parked the car? Lipsky is cold, feeling vulnerable, fighting tears.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: No. I didn’t, okay? Sorry! I fucked up. I’m a fuck-up. Not everyone can be as brilliant as you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What is with you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What the fuck is with you? They get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride in silence. Lipsky, at the wheel, collects his thoughts before speaking his mind. This is a more asserti Lipsky than we’ve seen before.  65.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I gotta say... There’s something basically false about your approach here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean “false?”

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I think it’s part of your whole social strategy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You still feel you’re smarter than other people.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah but you act like you’re in the kids’ softball game, but holding back your power-hitting, to try to make it more competitive for the little ones.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Here, now, for the past three days, it’s part of your social strategy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’re a tough room, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You make a point of holding back - there’s something obvious about you holding back your intelligence, to be with people who are younger or maybe not as agile as you are...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That would make me a real asshole, wouldn’t it? I don’t think writers are any smarter than other people. I think they may be more compelling in their stupidity, or in their confusion.  66. But I think one of the true ways that I have gotten smarter is, I’ve realized that I’m not much smarter than other people.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There are ways in which other people are a lot smarter than me. Like, I don't know, it makes me feel kinda lonely...

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There’s certain stuff I’ve told you that’s really true and, frankly, I think it’s been brave of me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’ve written enough of these “pieces” to know that you could present this in a hundred different ways. Ninety of which I’m really gonna come off as a monumental asshole. But it seems like your read of this is, “Huh: what an interesting persona Dave is adopting for the purposes of this interview.”

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That’s not what I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If we’d done this interview through the mail? And I had access to a library, and could look stuff up? My dream would be for you to write this up, send it to me, and I get to rewrite all my quotes - which of course you'll never do. When I’m in a room by myself, alone, and have enough time, I can be really really smart. Don’t get me wrong: I think I’m bright; I think I’m talented. I don’t mean to sound disingenuous.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (amused) Oh, no?!  67.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am not an idiot. I mean, you know, I can talk intelligently with you about stuff. But I can’t quite keep up with you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: That is such bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Believe me: I’m not just “Aw-shucks, I’m just in from the country, I’m not a real writer, I’m just a regular guy.” I’m not trying to lay some kind of shit. And I’m -

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You just did it again! You flatter me, but are you just being patronizing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I just think to look across the room and automatically assume that somebody else is less aware than me, or that somehow their interior life is less rich, and complicated, and acutely perceived than mine, makes me not as good a writer.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because that means I'm going to be performing for a faceless audience, instead of trying to have a conversation with a person. If you think that's faux, then you think what you want. I've got a serious fear of being a certain way. And a set I think of like, real convictions about why I'm continuing to do this, why it's worthwhile. Why it's not just an exercise in basically getting my dick sucked. And, you know what?, this is a very clever tactic of yours:

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Tactic, what tactic?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Get me a little pissed off, a little less guarded, I’m gonna reveal more.  95 96 68. Yes, it's true: I treasure my regular- guy-ness; I've started to think it's my biggest asset as a writer, that I'm pretty much just like everybody else. (A beat.) You know what? I’m not doing any kind of faux thing with you; I'm not gonna say it again.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay, but the faux thing - what you just said - is an example of the faux thing. You don't want to take the risk of giving the full you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t know if you’re a very nice man or not. It’s very clear that you don’t believe a word I've said.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: All your protesting... “I’m just a regular guy.” You don’t crack open a thousand-page book ‘cause you heard the author’s a regular guy. You read it because the author is brilliant. Because you want him to be brilliant. So who the fuck are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t have the brain cells left to play any kind of “faux” games with you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Fine. David presses stop on the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: In nasty weather, Lipsky fills the tank, leaving the cap the roof. David runs around to the other side of the car take over driving duty from Lipsky. They drive away.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/OUTSKIRTS
dialogues.text: Closer to home. Lipsky glances over at David, at the whee who seems faraway and depressed.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What are you thinking?  69.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tour’s over.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Just hit you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m gonna have to feel all this now, instead of just sleepwalk through it.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What do you mean by “sleepwalk?”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've kind of unplugged myself for the last three weeks. Meeting a whole lot of new people, having to do things, you're in a constant low-level state of anxiety. And sort of deep, existential, you know: fear, that you feel kind of all the way down to your butthole.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of? I mean, what’s the worst thing that could possibly happen?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The worst? That I’ll really get to like it. That’s the worst.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: The attention?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (nods, then) And what would be so wrong about that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Become one of these hideous: “Yet another publication party, and Hey, there’s Dave sticking his head in the back of the photo.” I’d rather be dead.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be seen that way. Why, would you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Well, if you're deriving your satisfaction from talking about your work, as opposed to writing, then, yeah, I guess you’d get a lot less done.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Exactly. And there’s nothing more grotesque than somebody who's going around, “I'm a writer, I’m a writer, I’m a writer.” Is that a dig at Lipsky? Lipsky thinks so.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t mind appearing in Rolling Stone, but I don’t want to appear in Rolling Stone as somebody who wants to be in Rolling Stone. If you see me like, you know, a guest on a game show in a couple of years... Lipsky laughs. Pause. David is pensive again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: To have written a book about how seductive image is, and how many ways there are to get seduced off any kind of meaningful path, because of the way the culture is now...? What if I become this parody of that very thing? Lipsky looks at David, who stares straight ahead, his eye maybe filling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, you drive away, get ona plane, this is over. And I’m back to knowing like twenty people. Then I’m going to have to like decompress from getting all this attention. Because it’s like getting heroin injected into your cortex. That registers with Lipsky.  97 71.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONTD)
dialogues.text: And where I’m going to need real balls is to be able to sit and go through that. And try to remind myself that what the reality is: that I’m thirty- four years old, and I’m alone ina room with a piece of paper. They drive in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grand Am pulls up, its headlights the only artificial light. The Davids get out and remove their bags. Inside, the dogs are barking in anticipation. David unlocks the door and the dogs greet him and Lipsky exuberantly. David kneels so that the dogs lick his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (in an Elvis voice) I’m never leavin’ you again, I swear. David looks around the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shit Check. (discovers some) Ah! Look what you did. The dogs sheepishly watch David clean up their shit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Happens to the best of us, eh, boy? Never fails. Wait to do your thing after the dog-sitter leaves. (to Lipsky) Be sure your Rolling Stone readers learn about that. David prepares to put on some music. Tape recorder in han Lipsky approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Uh. Hey. So, I’m leaving tomorrow and, I’ve got to ask you about this rumor...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is this the heroin thing? The heroin thing again?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  72.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It isn’t true. What is so hard for you to believe?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: The reason it is so hard to believe is because there is so much about drugs and addiction in the book...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean it’s autobiographical, the drug stuff in the book is basically a metaphor. Look at you. You don’t fucking believe a word I’m saying, do you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was not, I never was a heroin addict.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay. The rumor I heard... was that in the late ‘80s, when you were at Harvard, you'd gotten involved with drugs and had some kind of breakdown...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't know if I had a breakdown, I got really really depressed. I told you that. It had nothing to do with drugs. I mean, I'm somebody who spent most of his life in libraries. I never lived that kind of dangerous life. I wouldn't even stick a needle into my arm.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay, so how do you think that rumor got started?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I have no idea! I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Alright... Calm down...  73.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: To tell you truly, if you structured this as some “and then he spiraled into some terrible addiction thing,” it would be inaccurate. It was more like, I got more and more unhappy. The more unhappy I would get, the more I would drink. There was no joy in the drinking. I used it for anesthesia. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Okay. What kind of drinker were you? Were you a falling-down drinker? A waking-up-in-the-curb drinker?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, I was not! Okay? Part of my reticence about this whole thing is that it won't make very good copy for you. Because, no, I was not like that at all!

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You did agree to this interview.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know that I did.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Alright, I'm not gonna push much further.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm also aware that some addictions are sexier than others. My primary addiction my entire life has been to television. I told you that. Now, television addiction is of far less interest to your readers than something like heroin, that confirms the mythos of the writer -

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: A myth I do not believe, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know you don't believe that. I’m also aware that one of the things swirling around here is you want the best fucking article you can have!  100 101 74. Why don’t you write whatever the fuck you want, but the fact of the matter is, it was not a Lost Weekend sort of thing. Nor was it some lurid, romantic writer-as-alcoholic-sort-of-thing. What it was, was a 28-year-old person who exhausted a couple other ways to live, really taken them to their conclusion. Which for me was a pink room, with a drain in the center of the floor. Which is where they put me for an entire day when they thought I was going to kill myself. Where you don’t have anything on, and somebody's observing you through a slot in the wall. And when that happens to you, you become tremendously... unprecedentedly willing to examine some other alternatives for how to live. David looks at him for a moment. He walks out of the room leaving Lipsky behind, his head reeling. Lipsky presses s on the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky, still digesting the conversation, looks at himsel the mirror while brushing his teeth. He spits into the si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky is in bed, still awake in the moonlight. The door ajar, David comes in. He speaks softly, in shadow. He can be seen and can’t see Lipsky very well; it’s sort of like confession.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You awake?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was just thinking... It wasn't a chemical imbalance, and it wasn't drugs and alcohol. It was much more that I had lived an incredibly American life. That, “If I could just achieve X and Y and Z, everything would be OK.” (A beat.)  102 103 104 75. There's a thing in the book: when people jump out of a burning skyscraper, it's not that they're not afraid of falling anymore, it's that the alternative is so awful. And then you're invited to consider what could be so awful, that leaping to your death seems like an escape from it. I don't know if you've had any experience with this kind of thing. But it's worse than any kind of physical injury. It may be what in the old days was known as a spiritual crisis. Feeling as though every axiom of your life turned out to be false, and there was actually nothing, and you were nothing, and it was alla delusion. And that you were better than everyone else because you saw that it was a delusion, and yet you were worse because you can't fucking function. And it’s really horrible. (A beat.) I don’t think we ever change. I’m sure there are still those same parts of me. I’ve just got to find a way not to let them drive. Y'know? (A beat.) Well, anyway... Good night.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Good night. David goes. Lipsky, his eyes moist, scrambles to get his and scribbles notes so he won’t forget David at his most revealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light falls across Lipsky’s face. The dogs greet him. He stirs, gets up. INT. DAVID’S HOUSE/HALLWAY - 1996 - MORNING 103 Lipsky heads for the bathroom just as David emerges from

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Lipsky are out on a wintry field, walking the d  76.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jeeves, Drone, come! You get instantaneous production from the Jeevester; Drone’s a much tougher nut.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Beautiful out here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You should see: in the spring, when the wind blows, you can see ripples, it’s like water. It’s like the ocean, except it’s real green. I mean, it really is. Calm, real pretty. (Pause.) Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You know me. They turn back toward the house. David calls the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You should get going.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let me take you someplace nice this time. Remember, it’s on Jann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsy and David emerge. David tucks into the takeout bag.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sorry, I can’t wait, I’m suddenly starving, I gotta eat something. David picks pickles off his bacon double cheeseburger.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You don’t like pickles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. Now the whole world will know what my mother’s known for years: I'm a picky eater? He takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs are in David and Lipsky’s faces while the men ea  77.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jeeves, sit! You see, Jeeves gets very obedient when food is around. You sit, Drone. It should be clear by now that you’re not getting any of this. Drone sits. David feeds both dogs morsels of his food.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good dog! There you go, thatta boy. (to Lipsky) Don’t leave food within their reach - they will eat it. Lipsky takes a note.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna make me look like one of those insane old women who talk to their dogs, are you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am worried: my dogs’1l be offended.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Your dogs are not gonna read it. Drone playfully nudges Lipsky to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wow - he’s never taken to a male like he’s taken to you.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Except for me, of course. The phone rings. David hands Lipsky his burger.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hold this?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Sure. David goes to get the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Hello? Oh, hey.  78. He turns away from Lipsky and lowers his voice but Lipsky still hear him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I would like to. I can’t right now. I’ve got this guy here. Lipsky is stung: After all the intimacy they shared, Lips is just “this guy.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The Rolling Stone guy. Yeah. Well, he should be leaving pretty soon. Can I just meet you there? Okay? Great. See you there. Bye. He hangs up. Lipsky tries not to show his hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I should get out of here, let you get on with your life.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just this friend. This dance I like to go to, with this friend.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You dance?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uh huh. I’ve just discovered in the last few years that I really like it. Although I’m still not very good.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What kind of dancing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I tend to do the Jerk, the Swim, cheesy 70s disco.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The nice thing about Bloomington? You're completely hip if you do that.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Where do you go, a club?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This Baptist church.  79. Lipsky can’t tell if David is serious.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because Baptists can dance.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Wow. Dancing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I will not Vogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky, listening to David’s voice, smiles ruefully. DAVID’S VOICE (on tape) That’s the one thing I refuse to do: I will not Vogue. It’s cool. All these people come, and they’ve all got their dancing shoes on and stuff. And it’s nice. Everybody just, more or less, leaves each other alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene 107, continued.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey, before you leave, I would really like it if maybe we should exchange address data.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. (A beat.) Well, I should get my stuff together.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And I should start carving an ice sculpture out of my car. It’s like Antarctica. David grabs his coat and gloves and goes outside. Soon we hear the sound of David scraping ice off his car, which i heard throughout the following:  110 111
Lipsky goes from room to room, as if memorizing this time place, softly describing what he sees into his recorder.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (into the device) Dog stuff. Throw toys, chew toys. Crap stains on carpet. Shark doll on bookcase. American flag. Alanis. Coal-burning fireplace. Brick wall. Fake wood- paneling. dialogues.text: Barney towel used as curtain. Photo of German philosophers. Photo collage of his family, the kind kids put in their dorm rooms. His sister is pretty, looks like a female him. Clothes everywhere: sneakers, stuff on the floor, clothes draped over stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (CONT'D)

St. Ignatius quote: “Lord teach me to be generous. / Teach me to serve you as you deserve; / to give and not to count the cost... / to toil and not to seek for rest / to labor and not to ask for reward, / save that of knowing that I do your will.” INT. He pushes his way in and discovers a darkened room. looks around quietly, barely breathing, sees the partiall illuminated keyboard and computer. He goes to the closed drapes, pushes them aside and squints as he takes in the brilliant snowy field.  112 113 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scraping is still heard. Lipsky packs clothes, a loaf and stops when he sees his book, The Art Fair. He looks a his author's photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His book in hand, Lipsky trudges through the snow and fin David systematically scraping away at his car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Driving that rental of yours? The feeling of gliding? This shit box dudn’t even have shock absorbers.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘85 Nissan Sentra. I know it doesn’t look like much, but, man, this thing starts. It’s actually a problem.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I gotta get a new one but I can’t junk this.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's my friend.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Ah. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey, David, I, uh... Lipsky shyly presents David with a copy of his book.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wow. Just happened to have it on you?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I debated whether or not I should I do this.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, you don’t think this is like some kid-brother sort of thing to do?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. Thanks, man, I look forward to reading it.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. I wrote my address and e-mail on the flyleaf.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’ll read it soon as I’m done with the Heinlein and I’1l send you a note.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Great. Thanks. David flips through the book.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’1ll be curious to see what it’s like being inside your head for a change. I like your cover.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, me, too. I had them use the cover art for the British edition.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on. You got approval but I - ? (stops himself) It’s nice. It’s very nice. Lipsky puts his bag in the Grand Am and slams the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Hey, isn’t it reassuring that a lot of people are reading you and saying you're a really strong writer?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It'd be very interesting to talk to you in a few years.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?  115 83.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: ‘Cause my own experience is that that’s not so. The more people think that you’re really good, actually the bigger the fear of being a fraud is. The worst thing about having a lot of attention paid to you, is that you’re afraid of bad attention. If bad attention hurts you, then the calibre of the weapon that’s pointed at you has gone way up. Like from a .22 toa -45. But there’s a part of me that wants a lot of attention. And that thinks I’m really good, and wants other people to see it. It’s one of the ways I think we’re sort of alike, you know?

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Lipsky smiles and nods. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: (in farewell) Well... Lipsky’s awkward attempt at a hug - unreciprocated by Dav turns into a clumsy handshake. Lipsky gets into the car. David stands at his window.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure you want to be me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (A beat. He smiles.) Send my best to “Jann.” David shuts the door. Lipsky starts the car and pulls awa while David returns to scraping his car.

He excitedly slices open the box and peels away newspaper to reveal: A SINGLE LOAFER. a message written on a post-it: “Yours, I presume?” Accompanied by a smiley face. Nothing on the reverse. dialogues.text: When I think of this trip...

dialogues.text: (reads) ...I see David and me in the front seat of the car.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/OUTSKIRTS
dialogues.text: Flashes back to the car ride, as described. We see them talking but cannot hear them; all we hear is the sound of tires on the road.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We are both so young. He wants something better than he has; I want precisely what he has already. Neither of us knows where our lives are going to go. It smells like chewing tobacco, soda, and smoke. And the conversation is the best one I ever had.  120 123 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lipsky imagines, in slow-motion, David dancing joyously, sweating like crazy, with members of the church the night Lipsky left, the night that began the rest of his life.

dialogues.speaker: LIPSKY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: David thought books existed to stop you from feeling lonely. If I could, I'd say to David that living those days with him reminded me of what life is like -- instead of being a relief from it... and I’d tell him it made me feel much less alone. The screen suddenly goes black.
